docs.title: Annotations Module
docs.description: The annotations module includes a set of Spring-oriented annotations to make it easier to manage some AWE features.

docs.title: Accordion
docs.description: An accordion is a layout component that allows to organize the content in different sections that can be collapsed or expanded.  Inside its panels, it allows to have the same content as a window or a tag element, even nested accordions.

docs.title: Actions
docs.description: To perform an action when we click a button, or a dependency is activated, we need to define a button-action or a dependency-action. The format of these actions is the next one:

docs.title: Button
docs.description: A button is a graphical control element that provides the user a simple way to trigger an event, like searching for a query, or to interact with dialog boxes, like confirming an action.

docs.title: Charts
docs.description: AWE uses Highcharts library for chart development. This javascript library allows build many types of dynamic graphics easily, quickly and flexibly. It has no dependencies on any other library. ItÂ´s compatible with most current browsers and has high performance.

docs.title: Context menu
docs.description: Awe engine allows define context menu inside a grid, criterias or charts. With these menus, you can add functionality to your window.

docs.title: Criteria
docs.description: Criteria elements are window components which can get input from the user and send it to the application server (business logic).

docs.title: Dependencies
docs.description: Each component (criterion, grid, chart, etc) can have some dependencies inside affecting its behaviour and contents. A dependency can be launched depending on component conditions or events.

docs.title: Dialog
docs.description: A dialog is a graphical item that provides the functionality of showing a modal window with a selected message and title (and an icon, if you want). A dialog should be associated to a button-action with type "dialog" (See button actions).

docs.title: Email definition
docs.description: Note: All emails are defined in the Email.xml file at global folder. View project structure  for more info.

docs.title: Enumerate definition
docs.description: Enumerated components are structures to define label - value lists. They are useful i.e. for translations.

docs.title: Grids
docs.description: Grids are the main component in AWE to show data lists. It is defined by grid and columns:

docs.title: i18n-internationalization
docs.description: AWE implements a i18n system for internationalization of web applications. For this reason, AWE uses locale files containing literals in different languages.

docs.title: icons
docs.description: AWE has included some icons families to be used on components and grids.

docs.title: Include
docs.description: An include is a component which allows you to pick a screen piece and place it inside another screen. It's very useful to reuse a piece of code between screens.

docs.title: Navigation Bar
docs.description: The navigation bar is used to add visual elements with logic functions in the top zone of application. This part is displayed in all application screens.

docs.title: Layout
docs.description: AWE layout service helps the developer to position the screen layers taking advantage of all the screen size. There are two ways of 'expanding' the layout:

docs.title: Maintain definition
docs.description: The maintain engine is used to do operations that don't return data. These operations are valid for updating data in the server. They only return the result of proccess, if operation has been ok or if there has been a problem while doing the operation.

docs.title: Menu definition
docs.description: Navigation menu for an AWE application is defined in XML files. The two menu XML files are:

docs.title: Messages
docs.description: Message elements are messages to show after execute one action. Usually these message are described in the hidden section of the window.

docs.title: Pivot Table
docs.description: The pivot table is an analytic component which allows the user to generate custom reports from a dataset, and play with those data in several ways.

docs.title: Query definition
docs.description: The AWE query engine is used for querying data on external systems. It works as an interface.

docs.title: Queues definition
docs.description: The AWE Jms engine allows integration with queue servers. Both JMS typologies, point to point and publish/subscribe.

docs.title: Resizable
docs.description: A resizable is a container which can be resized grabbing one of its sides.

docs.title: Screen Element
docs.description: The screen is the container tag for all screen components. In this tag you have to define the JSP template the screen is going to render, the screen title (label), and some other features like the target, which is a list of queries to launch that will fill the criteria values.

docs.title: Screen Definition
docs.description: In AWE, screens are generated by an XML descriptor and a JSP template. HTML final pages are generated automatically based in those 2 files.

docs.title: Services Definition
docs.description: Service operations are designed to perform specific treatments and calculations out of the AWE utilities.

docs.title: Tab and tabcontainer
docs.description: A tab is a very useful screen component to separate the screen components in tabs:

docs.title: Tag
docs.description: Tags are basically HTML elements. They can be used to separate the different parts of the screen we want to generate.

docs.title: Template
docs.description: A template is a JSP file which contains a link between the AWE engine and the XML descriptor. Those links are called source points. Each JSP template has one or more source points. These source points are the places where our generated code in the XML descriptor will be located once each page is generated.

docs.title: Window
docs.description: A window is a container with a title bar. It also can be maximized or restored, and it's very useful to sort groups of components in the screen.

docs.title: Wizard and Wizard panel
docs.description: Introduction

docs.title: Application Options
docs.description: Application options are a way to add property values via database. Application options

docs.title: Architecture
docs.description: Table of Contents

docs.title: Builder Module
docs.description: Builder module is a set of Java utilities designed to cover some functionalities:

docs.title: Database migration
docs.description: AWE uses Flyway as default tool for database script version control.

docs.title: Deploying AWE Applications
docs.description: Intro

docs.title: DevTools Module
docs.description: This module has some very useful management tools to manage literals:

docs.title: DevTools Module
docs.description: This module has some very useful management tools to manage server resources:

docs.title: Debugging
docs.description: Debugging tools

docs.title: Default screens
docs.description: Introduction

docs.title: Dependencies between tasks
docs.description: Another powerful feature of the Scheduler module is the possibility of adding dependencies to a task. The dependencies are tasks that will be launched just after the parent task finishes. These dependencies can also contain other dependencies, creating a workflow.

docs.title: Notifications
docs.description: The notifier module improves AWE with a notification system. This system works the following way:

docs.title: Print engine
docs.description: AWE has a generic printing engine in order to print the content of a screen. This printing engine allows printing the content of a screen in pdf, excel and doc formats.

docs.title: Project Structure
docs.description: AWE (Almis Web Engine) is a web application development tool which allows the developer to create web application screens by describing the screen behaviour on a XML file.

docs.title: Schedule Tasks Configuration
docs.description: The scheduler is a powerful tool which allows to create any kind of schedule in a simple way.

docs.title: Scheduler
docs.description: This document gives a minimum base to start with the AWE Scheduler module, and explains how to automate and schedule tasks inside AWE in a simple way.

docs.title: Selenium Tests
docs.description: This document gives a basic insight on how to start developing Selenium tests for applications developed with AWE. Before starting test development, make sure to read the Selenium Test Development Guide, specially the Optimization/Help tips section. Basic aspects you should know before starting to develop Selenium tests, such as general configurations and integration with Jenkins, are not treated in this document.

docs.title: v4.0 Migration Guide
docs.description: Application Structure

docs.title: Validation
docs.description: The validation action checks the conditions of each criterion with a value under the validation attribute. This action is related with a validate type button (see button actions).

docs.title: Installation
docs.description: To install an AWE-based application just deploy it on an application server, like Apache Tomcat, Wildfly (old JBoss) or IBM WebSphere

docs.title: Almis Web Engine
docs.description: AWE is a light-weight Java web framework. Allows you build web applications in the fastest way.

docs.title: Logging
docs.description: AWE framework uses Logback for all internal logging but you can configure your project to use other libraries like JUL or Log4j2.

docs.title: Maven
docs.description: The maven dependencies needed to run an application with AWE engine are the next ones:

docs.title: Notifier Module
docs.description: The notifier module allows your users to subscribe to notifications in your application.

docs.title: Properties
docs.description: Introduction

docs.title: Purpose
docs.description: Table of Contents

docs.title: Rest API Module
docs.description: What's a REST api? REST stands for Representational State Transfer. (It is sometimes spelled "REST".) It

docs.title: Scheduler Module
docs.description: Scheduler module adds a powerful scheduling tool to your application

docs.title: Session config
docs.description: AWE allows developers to configure the application session in two ways: Using the default HttpSession (Basic session)

docs.title: awe-101 Your first AWE App
docs.description: Introduction

docs.title: awe-102 Windows design
docs.description: In this tutorial we will learn how to create screens with AWE and to layout the components needed for the screen as we wish.

docs.title: awe-103 Criteria, grids and charts
docs.description: The criteria elements are screen components that can be used by a user to insert and select sets of data and send them to the server. They are also used to filter the data shown in the screen and to introduce or modify data.

docs.title: awe-104 Data retrieval and manipulation
docs.description: The retrieval of data using AWE can be done from different sources: enumerated, queries, queues, services (Java and C), etc. This helps the integration of client side with the bussiness logic hosted in the server.

docs.title: awe-105 Develop module
docs.description: Developer module offers a series of tools designed to facilitate developer's tasks.

docs.title: awe-106 Actions and dependencies
docs.description: In this tutorial we will see how to give some dynamism to the screen that we have developed. Thanks to actions and dependencies it is possible to make requests to the server, to modify the content of a component given the values of other components or to change the attributes of a criteria.

docs.title: awe-107 Services
docs.description: Services within AWE are useful to execute any kind of bussiness logic on the server side. It can execute Java or C code to do whatever task we want to.

docs.description: The annotations module includes a set of Spring-oriented annotations to make it easier to manage some AWE features.

blogPosts.content: The AWE framework team is pleased to announce that starting with version 4.7.1, AWE will use the Spring Boot 3 and Spring 6 version as a base image. In this way, we will be prepared for new functionalities, greater security and of course, better maintenance. This version requires us to use **Java 17**, so you have to take this into account if you want to use the new version of AWE. To see more information about the new features of Spring Boot 3, you can see it on [this link](https://www.baeldung.com/spring-boot-3-spring-6-new). Next, we leave you the [migration guide](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/wiki/Spring-Boot-3.0-Migration-Guide) for AWE applications that use the new version of Spring Boot 3.

We have added a new security function to our framework: **Two-factor authentication**. This development adds the possibility to enable an extra authentication factor based on apps like **Google Authenticator** to enter the application. We have also added the possibility to force all the users to activate this second factor to improve access security. To see more information about this new functionality, you can read about it on [this link](/docs/security#two-factor-authentication-2fa)

`AWE Framework` now has a new _module_: **Notification module**. This module allows _very easily_ to create new topics and publish notifications over them. We also have developed a new `settings` screen to allow the user to subscribe to topics which he or she prefers via **notification** or **email**. To see more information about this new functionality, you can read about it on [this link](/docs/guides/notifier)

From `AWE` team we want to welcome you and open this new communication channel to everyone. We will publish `AWE framework` news as well as tutorials and other interesting things related to web application development. So, **welcome aboard!** :smile:
